Notes: Koyayeŋgeshould be considered as a 1st person possessive form ('my..')

Retroflex articulation in Betul and Mandla is strange and probably erroneous. Various epenthetic vowels in different dialects are due to developments*arjil>*arijl>*arijVl, on one side, and*arjil>*arVjil>*arVjl>*arVjVl, on the other.

Additional forms: Also caus. Gondi_Trarhuttānā, Gondi_Pharahtānā,arsahtānā, Gondi_Muarih-/arh-, Gondi_Sarah-, Gondi_A (SR)arusānāto cause to fall; Gondi_Korāl-to fall (< Telugu)

Also Gondi_Maavval(pl.avvasku) mother; Gondi_Lavālmother; Gondi_Trmaiwalmy mother (lit. our mother);mīwalthy mother (lit. your mother);awhāṛīmother, dam of man or beast; Gondi_Phavhā̆rīid. (for-harisee 2357)
Also Gondi_Trsohalē-jāṭāthe kōnch or cow-itch, Mucuna pruriens; Gondi_A (Su.)coh-,cohk-to itch
Also Gondi_Mu caus.hunjih-; Gondi_Muhuskaṛsleep; Gondi_Elwinhuskār, Gondi_Mauskaṛ,uskanḍid.
Also Gondi_Chd caus.huṛsutānāto show; Gondi_Whūṛsahtānāto reveal; Gondi_Ph, Gondi_Wsūrālblind
Notes: The formhupsānāis probably borrowed from Telugu.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Wāwsahtānāto dispatch; Gondi_Muavh-/avih-to make to reach, bring, obtain

Notes: The original quality of the vowel has been preserved in Gondi_S (īn<*iv-n) and Gondi_Ch, which alone of all dialects has preserved some traces of-v-in its former position:iyel<*iv-l<*iv-nR. In most other dialects vowel quality has been modified, and some preserved the original-v-by means of a metathese.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Trkanskstānāto send a dream (of god); Gondi_A (SR)kanjkānāto dream
Also Gondi_Phkarsahtānā, Gondi_Mukaṛih-to burn (tr.); Gondi_Mukaṛhafield for burning cultivation; Grigsonkarearea set apart for penda cultivation when left fallow for a term

Also Gondi_Akoṭelamallet; Gondi_Mu, Gondi_Makoṭeladrumstick; Gondi_Mukohk-to gore; Gondi_A (Su.)kohk-to grind into a paste, pound (in a mortar), beat stalks of millet, wheat, etc. on the ground so that the seeds fall down

Notes: The Gondi_Lu_S form is more archaic, as is shown by external data. The form itself literally means 'curved arm' (*kōnd-+*kāy-) and has undergone modifications in Gondi dialects, primarily in the direction*-ndk->*-nadk->*-naŋk-, although the reason of*-o->-u-is not quite clear (probably due to surrounding back consonants).

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Ymarnḍeyaṛfemale cross-cousin; Gondi_A (Su.)marṇḍū(pl.-r) male cross-cousin
